channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Central Banks Accept Pain Now, Fearing Worse Later
item.description: Federal Reserve officials and their counterparts around the world are trying to defeat inflation by rapidly raising interest rates. They know it will come at a cost.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers at a food bank in London. The Bank of England on Thursday raised interest rates by half a point to 2.25 percent, even as it said that the United Kingdom might already be in a recession.

item.title: Pandemic Unemployment Fraud Estimate Is Raised to $45.6 Billion
item.description: A federal watchdog tripled its earlier estimate of benefits that the U.S. government paid to people who weren’t entitled to them.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi

item.title: Russian Men, Fearing Ukraine Draft, Seek Refuge Abroad
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin’s new military call-up has sent young men who don’t want to fight in Ukraine heading to the borders.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Istanbul International Airport. With the government replenishing its military in Ukraine, some Russian men have headed for the borders.

item.title: Presidential Power to Declassify Information, Explained
item.description: In an interview, Mr. Trump again insisted that “I declassified everything.” He added that as president, “you can declassify just by saying ‘it’s declassified’ — even by thinking about it.”
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: A list of the items seized when the F.B.I. conducted a search at Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s club and residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: World Bank Leader, Accused of Climate Denial, Offers a New Response
item.description: David Malpass touched off a furor, including calls for his removal, when he refused to acknowledge that fossil fuels are warming the planet.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: David Malpass was nominated to lead the World Bank in 2019 by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: The Tonga Volcano Shook the World. It May Also Affect the Climate.
item.description: Scientists say water vapor injected into the stratosphere by the volcanic eruption in January may have a slight, though temporary, warming effect.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: National Institute Of Information and Communications Technology, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The eruption of the Hunga Tonga–Hunga Haʻapai volcano in the Pacific Ocean, seen by a Japanese satellite on Jan. 15.

item.title: 2 Michael Jackson Impersonators Look Identical. The Resemblance Ends There.
item.description: Two imitators of the King of Pop in Buenos Aires offer a study in contrasts, reflective of Argentina’s deep economic divide. One man financed 13 surgeries, while the other draws on his sideburns.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Anita Pouchard Serra
item.media:description: Leo Blanco is a Michael Jackson impersonator in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

item.title: House Passes Police Funding Bills, With Democratic Rifts on Vivid Display
item.description: Progressive objections to the legislation threatened to sink it at the last moment, prompting a scramble among Democrats that highlighted the party’s divisions over policing.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Stephanie Lai
item.media:description: The House on Thursday passed legislation to increase funding for local police departments, but progressives initially balked at sending money to police departments without stronger accountability measures to address excessive use of force or other misconduct.

item.title: Herschel Walker’s Company Said It Donated Profits, but Evidence Is Scant
item.description: The Georgia Republican candidate claimed his business donated 15 percent of its profits to charities. Three of the four groups named as recipients say they didn’t receive money.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Herschel Walker at a state Republican Party event in Perry, Ga., last month. As a business owner, he pledged that 15 percent of his company’s profits would go to charities.

item.title: Secretary of State Races Turn Rowdy During the Homestretch
item.description: Democrats are outspending Republicans in Georgia, Michigan, Minnesota and Nevada, where they see their opponents as threats to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Ash Ponders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Finchem at a rally with Donald Trump for Republican candidates in Arizona in July. He won the primary for secretary of state by falsely claiming that the 2020 election was stolen.

item.title: Democrats’ Departures Narrow Path to Holding the House Majority
item.description: Democrats are defending more than a dozen seats in which the incumbent has said they will not run for re-election, complicating their effort to stop Republicans from reclaiming the House majority.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Representative Cheri Bustos and Steny Hoyer, the House majority leader, in March. Ms. Bustos is retiring at the end of her term.

item.title: Mississippi Welfare Scandal Spreads Well Beyond Brett Favre
item.description: Millions earmarked for the needy in the nation’s poorest state instead went to projects that benefited the well-to-do, the state alleges, including a volleyball stadium at Mr. Favre’s alma mater.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: The former N.F.L. quarterback Brett Favre finds himself in the middle of a sprawling scandal in Mississippi.

item.title: Zach Bryan Is Music’s Most Reluctant New Star
item.description: The Navy veteran — who blends folk, rock and country — has had a breakthrough year with his major-label debut, “American Heartbreak.” But fame isn’t what he’s after.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Kristin Braga Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bryan records and releases music at a furious pace. “I have this weird fear of like, if I don’t put this music out, someone 20 years from now isn’t going to be able to hear it,” he said.

item.title: The Inside Joke That Became Trump’s Big Lie
item.description: The lie that Trump won the 2020 election has grown so powerful because it is yoked to an older deception: the idea that American politics is a joke.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada

item.title: What Explains the Alarming Democrat-on-Democrat Sabotage in North Carolina?
item.description: The heir apparent to the current governor is the target of an absolutely baffling prosecution.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni

item.title: Public Schools Will Be on the Ballot in November
item.description: Why I’m worried about some parents’ loss of faith in the education system.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

item.title: Russia’s Putin Is in Trouble
item.description: The ground beneath his feet has started to shift.
item.dc:creator: Marlene Laruelle

item.title: Moderate Republicans No Longer Have a Home, and It Started With My Defeat
item.description: A former congressman on their decline and how it’s hurting the party.
item.dc:creator: Peter Smith
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Mint Images via Getty Images

item.title: I Have Worked, Played and Loved in Other Countries Because I Can’t at Home
item.description: In Singapore, queers see progress only from a distance.
item.dc:creator: Joel Tan

item.title: The Midlife Crisis Is Very Real and Nothing to Be Laughed At
item.description: It may be a result of our affluent world. Or it may be biological.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: Betrayal and Blackouts in Puerto Rico
item.description: It is our own people who rob and abuse us.
item.dc:creator: Israel Meléndez Ayala
item.media:description: Protesters outside the governor’s mansion La Fortaleza in San Juan, Puerto Rico in July.

item.title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Flights out of Russia were nearly fully booked this week.

item.title: Popcast Live! The New Faces of 2022
item.description: Blondshell, Central Cee, Ethel Cain and more: a conversation about what’s breaking through, plus questions from the audience at our first live taping.
item.media:credit: Irina Rozovsky for The New York Times

item.title: A Pesto for Every Pantry and Mood
item.description: Use the Ligurian sauce as a guideline and make tastier sandwiches, soups, pastas, gratins and more.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Jessica Emily Marx for The New York Times

item.title: 高铁上的卫生巾和浸透血水的防护服
item.description: 平均而言，女性一生中有2535天处于经期，常年忍受痛苦和不便，但月经仍被视为一种禁忌甚至耻辱。一场关于高铁上是否应该卖卫生巾的讨论再次凸显出中国社会对女性的忽视和女性争取权益的困境。
item.dc:creator: Zhan Juan
item.media:description: 武汉疫情最严重的时期，被运送到当地医院的卫生巾。

item.title: Boeing Reaches $200 Million Settlement Over Its 737 Max
item.description: The S.E.C. said Boeing had misled investors by suggesting that human error was to blame for two deadly crashes, and omitting the company’s concerns about the plane.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: Boeing 737 Max airplanes were grounded for nearly two years after deadly crashes in 2018 and 2019.

item.title: Nazi Sympathizer Is Sentenced to 4 Years Over Role in Jan. 6 Attack
item.description: The defendant’s “racist and antisemitic motivation” for trying to halt the election certification process set his case apart from dozens of other rioters, a judge said.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rioters surrounding the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: California Regents Hear Out Pac-12 on Whether to Block U.C.L.A.’s Move to Big Ten
item.description: The leaders of the sprawling University of California educational system are considering whether they should halt the move by U.C.L.A.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Gary A. Vasquez/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: U.C.L.A., which plays some of its football games at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., has struggled with attendance at the start of this season.

item.title: New System Aims to Save Whales Near San Francisco From Ship Collisions
item.description: Four whales have died near San Francisco this year after ships crashed into them, and scientists hope to drive that number to zero with new technology.
item.dc:creator: Alex Fox
item.media:credit: Dexter Hake for The New York Times

item.title: Can You Get the New Covid Booster and Flu Shot at the Same Time?
item.description: Combining vaccines may be more convenient, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times

item.title: What Is Legionnaires’ Disease and How Can I Protect Myself?
item.description: Nearly one out of every 10 people who gets sick with Legionnaires’ dies because of complications from the illness. Here’s what to know about prevention, detection and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: Why a Child’s Rude Behavior May Be Good for Development
item.description: The safer children feel, the more they can show their true selves — warts and all — experts say. And that’s good for their development.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Can Stimulating the Vagus Nerve Improve Mental Health?
item.description: On social media, exercises that aim to “tone” one of our body’s longest nerves have been touted as a cure-all for anxiety and other psychological ailments. Here’s what the research says.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Why L.G.B.T.Q. Adults Are More Vulnerable to Heart Disease
item.description: Experts say that a leading cause of death often goes overlooked.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Joan Didion’s Memorial Service Was a Star-Studded Evening
item.description: Among the well-wishers at Joan Didion’s memorial service in New York.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Bernstein
item.media:credit: Gus Powell for The New York Times

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
